entry.title: Linearity defects of powers are eventually constant
entry.summary: The linearity defect, introduced by Herzog and Iyengar in 2005, is a measure for the complexity of modules without a linear free resolution. We consider the asymptotic properties of linearity defect of powers of an ideal. We prove that if the base ring is regular local, large enough powers of a given proper ideal have constant linearity defect. We give an upper bound for the first point when linearity defect becomes a constant. To provide concrete examples, we compute the linearity defect of powers of certain sums and fibre products of componentwise linear ideals. In particular, we prove that the fibre product of two ideals $J, L$ over two polynomial rings has componentwise linear powers if and only if $J$ and $L$ have componentwise linear powers.
